subject: RE: [junit] Websphere Connection Pool
msgSnippet: loop: test everything get bored loop: test the important stuff write some stuff that can t break without tests until what can t break breaks endloop So
messageBody:
loop:
test everything
get bored
loop:
test "the important stuff"
write some stuff that "can't break" without tests
until what "can't break" breaks
endloop

So said john.link@... on 2003-02-04 --------------------

>> If your method does nothing to delegate to someone else, then
testing
>> your method is the same as testing the method to which the
>> implementation delegates; therefore, test the delegate, and not the
>> current method. The only thing that can break is an invalid (null)
>> reference, and you've probably testing for that somewhere else.
>>
>
>I followed that path until I was bitten some day: When delegating more
than
>one method - eg in a wrapper - I often code the delegation methods by
>typing
>in the first method, copying this method as often as needed and then
>renaming
>method names and delegation calls. Doing that without tests - and
without a
>pair coder - I introduced two nasty bugs... This becomes even more of
an
>issue when the interface of both delegate and delegee grows, I let the
IDE
>create
>the method stub and evetually forget to fill in the method body.
>
>Has someone detected a fool-proof (Johannes-proof) way of writing
>delegation
>code to prevent that kind of error? I guess delegation should part of
the
>language spec the same way implementation inheritance is. For
instance,
>Ruby
>does that in a nice way.
>
>Johannes
